newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks slump on auction hike, certification.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks slump on auction hike, certification.

text.p: Mexican stocks pared losses at the close on Wednesday but still ended sharply down for the second day in a row.
Traders said share prices fell on a combination of soaring primary rates and uncertainty over a bill to certify Mexico's anti-drug fight in the U.S. Congress.
"We recovered a little twards the close on the back of the Dow Jones," a Mexico City floor trader said.
The leading IPC share index closed down 46.03 points, or 1.21 percent, at 3,758.09.
The IPC probed support, analysts said, to reach a low of 3,747.79 points in late trade.
On Wall Street, the Dow Jones pared losses to close 0.65 percent lower at 7,039.37 points.
Bellwether 28-day Cetes rates climbed 201 basis points to 23.17 percent at Tuesday evening's primary auction, compared to an average increase of 93 basis points predicted in a Reuters survey.
Analysts said continuing fears over the debate in the U.S. Congress to decertify Mexico exacerbated jitters triggered by high interest rates.

"The market is still nervous and there has been no news to revive it. And then the Mexico (drug war) certification process is making waves," said Jaime Fernandez, an equity analyst at the Interacciones brokerage.
The U.S. House of Representatives Rules committee cleared the way for a vote on a bill on Thursday to decertify Mexico as an ally in the drugs war.
News came in late trade that Deputy U.S. Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers said decertification "would not be salutary" for the Mexican economy.
"Furthermore, foreign investors are staying away as they feel the peso is still a little too firm," Fernandez added.
Benchmark 48-hour peso contracts closed 0.1 of a centavo firmer at 7.9670/7.9700 per dollar.
The lack of foreign investors could be seen in trading volume of 105.9 million shares, of which cross trades accounted for one-third.
Telecomms firm Telmex L shares, down 12 centavos to 15.88 pesos, weighed most heavily on the market after accounting for 9 percent of all shares traded.
Dealers drew attention to a fall below the $40 barrier by Telmex ADRs, which ended off 5/8 at 39-1/2.
"I think telmex fell on market conditions. It moved ahead, but definitely hit the IPC," a desk trader said.
"I don't think the wage claim had an effect, but it could have been a pretext to take profits."

Mexico's Telephonists' Union asked Telmex for a wage rise of 47.43 percent during the day, to which the company will reply on April 4. The union has called for a strike on April 25 if their demands are not satisfied.
On the broad market, 103 stocks were traded, of which decliners outnumbered gainers by 72 to 17.

Traders also noted sharp gains posted by restaurant franchise holder ECE, which launched a primary and secondary public offering on Wednesday. ECE gained 40 centavos from its issue price to close at 11.40 pesos.
((--Karina Balderas, Mexico City newsroom +525 728-9562))
